subtitle: New Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today, we are going to explore the topic of philosophical midwifery.
With me is the author of the book, Philosophical
Midwifery, A New Paradigm for Understanding
Human Problems, Dr. Pierre Grimes, who is the founder of the American Philosophical
Practitioners Association, is also the founder
of the Noetic Society, based in Los Angeles.
He is the author of a number of other books,
The Pocket Pierre and Unblocking, which is
based on the principles of philosophical midwifery.
It's a practice akin to psychotherapy that takes place within a philosophical milieu.
Welcome, Pierre.
Pleasure.
It's a pleasure once again to be with you.
I guess one could say a philosophical practitioner
such as yourself is something of a hybrid
between a philosopher and a psychotherapist.
That's correct.
That's correct.
And you've been engaged in this practice now for a good 30 years.
Well, it started in 1961 with a publication I
did called Alcibiades, and it was a dialogue
I wrote featuring Socrates and Alcibiades, who I characterized as an alcoholic.
And therefore, I explored Alcibiades' alcoholic
addiction, alcoholism, in terms of the roots
of how he came to be an alcoholic.
And I wrote it up as a dialogue, and I sent it to Dale Journal.
They had a journal at that time studying alcoholism, and they were very upset.
They wrote me a letter, and they said it caused
a great deal of difficulty among the editorial
board, so they sent it to another magazine.
And the same thing happened there.
And so they sent it back to Yale, and they said, please print it.
So that's how it got printed.
So it started, therefore, as an exploration of Adwifery.
And so it's been since 1960.
So that's a little more than—
It's half a century.
Half a century.
Yeah.
A little over half a century, to be specific.
Well, how did you arrive at a term like midwifery?
I know there's a history there.
Okay.
See, I was involved in the study of Plato
and classic thought for some time, and I had
been studying dialogues, trying to understand the dynamics of a dialogue.
And I was going to graduate school in San Francisco.
This was in 1964, and I needed a job.
I had a wife and several children, and unfortunately, you know, you need to eat.
So I was never given enough money to live like a gentleman, so I decided I would be
having to find work.
So I went to the Public Welfare Department
in San Francisco, and they said, yeah, we'll
hire you if you want to take a job working with alcoholics on Skid Row.
I said, oh, I'll do that.
I had some people that were alcoholics in my family.
And so I became a social worker working with alcoholics.
Then they started a rehabilitation center in
Redwood City after only just a few months.
And since I was the only one who was working
specifically with alcoholics in Skid Row,
they said, you go.
So I became the social worker identified as the counselor.
And so I would just be at the center, and
I'd say to my alcoholics, tell me about your
last drunk, and we'd chart it out on the blackboards.
That's all we did.
I said, I want to understand you guys.
I don't understand the drunk.
So I started working with chronic alcoholics.
They came back periodically.
And I began seeing patterns, or didn't understand
why the patterns existed when they got a drunk
and when they came off a drunk became significant.
So I had this PhD chemist, and he was a chronic alcoholic, periodic alcoholic.
And we used to have great meetings, he'd come back and back.
So one day we had charted out his pattern where we were saying, well, now why are you
going through the same thing?
Notice you seem to start just after you've had close to a victory, and you end up in
a hospital.
What's going on?
It's the same thing.
Yeah.
Self-sabotage.
Yes.
Sabotaging himself.
Yeah.
He said, you know what, this may not be important.
But you know, I keep getting this image, an
old image of, I said, well, go ahead and talk
about it.
And he said, my mother used to come out to me, and he said, you know, when I was a kid
we used to play football out, and of course in
those days we didn't have uniforms or anything
like that.
We just played in the dirt, and it was somewhat
dangerous, and my mother, she stood there
by the doorway and she'd say, son, I want you to come home either with your shield or
without it.
They were Greeks.
That was the old Spartan slogan.
He said, you know, I think that's what I'm doing.
He said, after every drunk I'm being carried home on a stretcher.
I'm coming home on my shield.
I said, yeah, but what do you make of your mother?
He said, you know, this is rather curious, he said, but you know, she was very busy.
We had a lot of children.
She said, you know, those were the moments
she appeared most beautiful to me and caring.
As a matter of fact, that was the only time I really got that much attention from her
at that moment.
I said, oh, really?
What do you make of that?
He said, well, that's love, that's caring.
I'm reenacting that moment, that great moment.
I'm acting it out again and again.
I said, that's remarkable.
That became the beginning of philosophical midwifery, he said.
But the term midwifery, I mean, the midwife assists in a birth.
And I gather that the philosopher who is a midwife is giving birth to the soul.
Yes.
And this is what this is, giving birth to the soul.
But I was also into Proclus in those days.
And Proclus calls Socrates a midwife.
He said, this is midwifery.
And I said, well, that's what I'm doing.
I'm a midwife.
So that's where the term philosophical midwifery came out of.
And then when I worked out the details of
it, of course, then I then discovered it was
the same dynamics that occurred in Homer's Iliad.
But I chose it because I should just mention
that we discussed this in a previous interview,
the story of how Achilles came to a realization
of his own patterns and therefore was willing
finally to enter into battle after he had withdrawn.
So that's the reference to the Iliad.
And if people want more detail on that, I will post a link to that interview.
Oh, great.
Yeah.
Right.
Yes, yes, yes.
And from that, I did this dialogue, I called out Socrates, and it got published.
And then I didn't realize the significance of it, the implications of it for several
years.
And I said to myself, Pierre, maybe you're a psychologist.
Maybe you're really a psychologist, you're really not a philosopher.
So I said, I better start over.
So I packed up the family in San Francisco after I got my degrees.
And I said, I think I'm going to study psychology
at the New School of Research in New York
City, so I joined them.
And what I found there was a disaster.
I found that they didn't know what they were doing.
We were studying at that time the Minnesota
Symposium on Motivations, and they had a classic
example we spent our time studying.
And it was 50, a number of parachutists, they
were volunteers, they were all wired up on
all kinds of electronic devices in order to test the level of anxiety.
And they were, we were into Dollard and, what's the other guy's name?
Miller and Dollar.
Miller and Dollar.
Yes.
And they had the gradient where you should watch the curve of anxiety, of withdrawal
and escape, approach and avoidance.
Yes, yes.
And reminds me very much already of my first
encounter with clinical psychology and behaviorism.
I had a job fresh out of college at a place called the Singer Zone Center in Rockford,
Illinois.
It decided itself on being ten years ahead of the times, and I lasted six weeks.
So
Oh, well then we're similar because what happened
is that the parachutists, by every indication
they were wired in all variety of ways, their level of anxiety said escape.
But they continued up the ladder into the plan and jumped.
I said, gentlemen, your theory is false.
They should have withdrawn.
They should not have gotten on the plan.
What are you teaching?
They said, oh, no, no, no.
This is a good study.
I said, of course it's a good study.
It shows that your theories are false.
Well that ended my career at the New School of Social Research.
I decided the best thing to do is to look
for a teaching job doing philosophy and spend
my time doing philosophy.
Well, I understand exactly where you're coming
from because one might naively assume, especially
with a background in philosophy, that psychologists
are interested in the psyche, and it turns
out they're not.
They're not.
That's right.
You see, I went under the sunken and I found out they got very bitter.
They got upset at my views.
I said, well, gentlemen, I might as well leave.
They want to claim the name psyche and their
name psychology, but they really don't want
to have anything to do with it except recently.
Now they're beginning to look at the psyche.
But for the most part, they prefer to be thought of as behavioral scientists.
You know, that's very sad, and it's true.
They started aping physics, Newtonian physics, and empirical methods.
And the psyche is not in that realm, the psyche is in the realm of the mind.
And so I decided, well, the best thing to do is do my own studies and continue.
So I got a position in Southern California, and I started exploring problems, and out
of that came a club.
We started a club, and then the school got upset with having a club, so we moved off
to campus and started the Noetic Society, and that's how it began.
But the basic idea, as I gather, is that you
used the Socratic method in order to uncover
what you call the pathologos, meaning false ideas we have about ourselves.
And when people are conscious of what had previously been unconscious with regard to
their very being, then there's some movement.
Yeah, there's growth, first of all.
See, then the stage came when I was looking then at the need to explore daydreams.
Now, daydreams are the same thing, except for one factor.
There are five kinds of daydreams.
I like the tangent daydreams, that when anyone
is involved in something that takes their
attention and their focus of their energies and
they need to devote themselves very carefully
to the content of something, especially in intellectual work, anything that interrupts
that is a tangent.
That tangent is likely to contain an image of themselves or a daydream.
My goal, then, is to get people to write down
their daydream and only ask a few questions,
such as describe the first moment you have the
daydream where you have an image of yourself.
Imagine yourself, I don't need to examine your daydream.
You can examine the daydream yourself and see that what is implicit in that image is
the drama of the daydream.
What's significant is when you allow it to
go its full course, you wake up to recognize
it's false because it's a failure.
There are always failures in tangent daydreams.
Oh.
I said, now look here.
Why is it you identify it, therefore, with the false image of yourself?
You don't realize that that is your false image of yourself because you identify with
it immediately when it occurs.
You allow it to play itself out, therefore, now that we know we now can identify your
false image of the self, let's see if we can discover its origin.
Now why is a daydream necessarily a false image?
Couldn't it also be simply the mind scanning
for potential problems so that they can be
avoided?
That might be, but that's not a tangent daydream.
Okay.
There can be other kinds of daydreams and that is true.
I see.
But tangent daydreams, you see you're pursuing
something you love, you're pursuing, anytime
you pursue anything that you love and you
think of meaningful, that's when you get your
blocks.
That's the nature of a problem.
And philosophical midwifery, you can anticipate
whenever you're doing what you truly love
and what is meaningful to you, you'll get a block.
In other words, we're coming back to the issue of self-sabotage.
Yes.
Okay.
That's essential in our philosophical midwifery.
Therefore, you can anticipate it, you can look
forward to it, and now you can ask questions
such as, all you have to do is describe the state of mind that you experienced at that
moment when that self-sabotage occurred.
Describe it.
Then see whether you can look for analogous circumstances to that state of mind.
Not an association, but a similarity with that state of mind.
Look for earlier and earlier events of it.
It's worthwhile even if you get four or five
as you retreat back into your early life.
Look for the earliest one.
Then you'll see it will occur in an event where that's where it began.
Invariably what happens at that time is that
you were free, open, alive, finding experience
of reality beautiful, and the imposition comes
down upon you, and therefore you give it up.
What's interesting though is that if you're
doing something that is very creative, you'll
give up your creativity, and therefore you suffer that loss, and that produces anger
within you, subject to some injustice, and
that festers the wound as it were, and you're
angry but you can't show it.
So you look for some other situation where
you can then project it upon, and that becomes
your life.
So midwifery is to try to trace it back, but we go further.
We say, now look here, it's important therefore
for you to tell me what you think is most
important to you that you gave up.
Go back to it.
Go back to your most important challenge.
Take it on and let's see how well you can do it and master it.
In that mastery you'll discover naturally the
block that will block you, the self-sabotage
will occur.
Then we again ask the same questions.
What are they?
Can you please put that experience into words?
There are examples of it.
You'll find them in several places.
You go back to the earliest one.
You try to reconstruct that event so you can
see the dynamics of it and then relate it
to the present, midwifery.
It sounds very much like psychotherapy, to be honest.
But why don't they do it?
Well a lot of psychotherapy does involve uncovering early childhood trauma.
But they don't link it to such a meaningful event.
They are pursuing anxiety.
We are exploring anger.
I know in psychotherapy it's often the term you hear is catharsis.
Once you get in touch with that anger and
express it, the idea is you have had a catharsis
and the problem will kind of dissipate.
That's true.
But you can always find several episodes.
The important thing is to find its origin, not to express it.
Feeling, by the way, expressing it is very good for the person they feel good.
We want to go to its origin, not to its manifestation.
That's its essential difference.
Do you see the origin as an early childhood trauma or something else?
There's never a trauma.
You don't call it a trauma.
It's not a trauma.
In one way it's not a trauma because there's
no punishment, there's no injury inflicted.
The parent is seeing a child in an ideal state
and they're imposing a restriction upon it.
Because the parent views the ideal state as this is mischief.
Yes, a potentially mischief, yes, and dangerous to them.
But the state itself is not a trauma.
Enjoying the mischief, it's wonderful mischief.
Yes, therefore it's not a trauma.
But often the parent may discipline the child, it could be brutal.
Need not be.
Okay.
Need not be at all.
Yeah.
But in my understanding-
All it has to be is a withdrawal of affection.
Or the parent might simply say you're a bad person.
Well, you know, look at the story of the first
story I mentioned of the mother who stood
in the doorway and looks beautiful and tells
the child, I want you to come home either
with your shield or on it.
She looks beautiful.
Yeah.
So it's not necessarily traumatic.
It's not traumatic.
Well, but it could be.
Well, I would say the number of situations that were traumatic are rare.
Oh, now that's very interesting because, I mean, the conventional view in psychology
I think these days is that early childhood
trauma is far more common than we ever thought
and that almost every psychopathology can be traced to one.
You see, from that event, from the early event,
the parent may be so angered at the child
repeating these episodes they may in fact inflict some kind of injury upon the child.
Yeah.
That's not the same thing.
That will be an example where the child is angry or in fear, fear produces anxiety.
This is not fear.
So you're really not delving much into the area of, let's say, sexual abuse, physical
abuse, emotional abuse by the parent.
You're looking at something more subtle.
Yes.
Yes.
You see, there are times when I have explored
where a child may have gone through some sexual
abuse, right?
But invariably what we're looking at is why did the person take advantage of the child?
Yeah.
Because the child appeared to them most
beautiful and open and we have the same dynamic.
I see.
But those, if I were to make a statement in terms of how many out of how many.
Sexual trauma is the child knows what went on.
They're angry at that.
They fear it.
They fear its recurrence.
That's not the same thing as discovering the false belief.
Now why does the child from that event get a false belief?
This is very important.
In the scenes we're talking about where they
were doing something that was very beautiful
to them, very meaningful to them.
They don't understand why the parents suddenly turned against them.
They have to walk away saying there must be
something wrong with me, but they can't believe
that their parents are trying to block them from a meaningful experience.
They don't have the age and the intelligence yet to make that judgment.
So they blame themselves, that blaming themselves
to characterize themselves in a certain way
is the false image of the self.
And that's what you call the?
Pathologos.
Pathologos.
Right.
And I love that term, pathologos, because
it relates to a term everybody has heard of,
the logos.
Yes.
Yes.
And the logos seems to be practically the opposite of the pathologos.
That's right.
The method of analysis is the logos, which
is we use the same questions in the same way
always.
No need to vary it except minor circumstances,
but essentially the same questions are always
going to be asked, which is the same way we would use so far.
Say, let's see, you were trying to achieve your goal, oh, oh, and you were blocked.
Can you put that in words?
What was it like?
What did you feel at that time?
Careful of your microphones.
Yeah.
What did you feel at that time?
Oh, you get a description of that.
Where did you have that description?
Where did you describe that in your past?
Oh, you have several events, let's look at each one.
By the way, sooner or later we're going to have to go for the earliest one.
Oh, yes, we will.
Always the same.
So if I understand you correctly, the logos also in this process, it becomes like the
inner wisdom of the person, the kind of, one might say higher self.
It's always there.
It's always there.
It's always there.
It's remarkable that it's there.
And it's remarkable that such understanding can free them of their problem.
Wow.
Like realization is the result of coming to grips with something that occurred to you
that you didn't understand, therefore understanding is primary for your growth.
Well, then that means that life is meaningful.
That means you cannot block someone's growth
without injuring them for the rest of their
life.
Yeah.
But that's why we should save criminals.
That's why we should save these people who are terrorists.
We shouldn't say, look here, let's see what made you what you are, so we can then try
to understand it.
That's reason.
That's making a rational life.
But there's also the issue of how we block ourselves.
Whenever we block ourselves, see, that's what we do.
Whenever we learn, we apply to ourselves, we become a teacher of ourselves.
We become our worst teacher of ourselves because we're imitating a past teacher.
Uh-oh.
I always tell the people I work with, if you
don't solve your problem, don't worry, you'll
do it to your child.
No problem.
No problem.
You'll see you'll be doing it to your child.
And of course, no parent really wants to do
that, but the antidote seems to be inner work.
Yes.
See, I got the first glimpse of this myself when I, my first couple years of marriage.
My son Peter was on a tricycle.
We lived in San Francisco and it was one of the opposite store, one of the walk-ups.
And I got home and I was watching him.
He didn't see I was home.
I was walking up the steps.
And he's going back and forth on his tricycle
over a grate where the hot air came, the heat
of the apartment.
And I was watching him and I kept watching him.
I didn't know why I was watching him.
I saw I was absorbed in it and I screamed at him.
I never screamed at him before.
I yelled at him, what the hell are you doing?
And I didn't know why I was doing it.
I carried that for a long, long time saying,
hey, you know, you don't understand yourself
because here's the kid you love and look what you're doing.
You're scaring the hell out of him.
What for?
He's riding a tricycle over a grate?
See, then later I could see he was really in
an ideal state, having a great time, freedom
in himself.
And I was worried about that state, allowing
that state to perpetuate itself and continue
and maybe even deepen.
And I wanted to protect him and I didn't realize
any of that was true until another ten, fifteen
years down the road.
You were trying to protect him from his own best nature.
Yes.
Yes.
And I carried that.
An important insight for every parent.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Well, Pierre Grimes, once again, once again,
a very profound, meaningful time together.
I look forward to seeing you often in the future.
I know we'll have a lot to talk about.
Very good.
And I'm sure our viewers will appreciate it as well.
Thank you for being with me.
Thank you.
And thank you for being with us.
